article.title: Economy_of_American_Samoa
article.paragraph: Use dmy datesJuly 2013unreferencedFebruary 2011Infobox economyAmerican Samoa Dollarbill4.jpg 290px [[United States dollar|US dollar]] (USD) 1 October - 30 September none [[List of countries by GDP (nominal)|187th]] (nominal) / [[List of countries by GDP (PPP)|190th]] (PPP) $537 million (2007 est) 3% (2003) $7,874 (2008) NA NA NA 17,630 (2007) agriculture 34%, industry 33%, services 33% (1990) 23.8% (2010) tuna canneries (largely dependent on foreign fishing vessels), handicrafts $445.6 million (2004) canned tuna 93% (2004) [[Indonesia]] 70%, Australia 6.7%, Japan 6.7%, [[Samoa]] 6.7% (2002) $308.8 million (2004) materials for canneries 56%, food 8%, petroleum products 7%, machinery and parts 6% (2004) Australia 36.6%, New Zealand 20.3%, [[South Korea]] 16.3%, [[Mauritius]] 4.9% (2002) NA $121 million (37% in local revenue and 63% in US grants) (1997) $127 million (1997) more than $40 million from US in financial support (1994) aq US The economy ofAmerican Samoais a traditionalPolynesianeconomy in which more than 90% of the land is communally owned. Economic activity is strongly linked to the United States, with which American Samoa conducts the great bulk of itsforeign trade.TunaCommercial fishingfishingandFish processingprocessingplants are the backbone of the private sector, with canned tuna being the primary export. Transfers from theFederal government of the United StatesU.S. federal governmentadd substantially to American Samoa's economic well-being. Attempts by the government to develop a larger and broader economy are restrained by Samoa's remote location, its limited transportation, and its devastating hurricanes.Tourism, a developing sector, may be held back by the current financial difficulties inEast Asia.
